pli-tv-kd6:8.1.4: _Sindhava_. _Sindhavanti setavaṇṇaṁ pabbate uṭṭhahati_, “_Sindhava_: it appears as a white color in the hills.” | _Ubbhida_. _Ubbhidanti bhūmito aṅkuraṁ uṭṭhahati_, “_Ubbhida_ it appears like a sprout from the earth.” But Sp-ṭ.3.3.263 says: _Ubbhidaṁ nāma ūsarapaṁsumayaṁ_, “What is made from saline soil is called _ubbhidaṁ_.” | _Bila_. _Bilanti dabbasambhārehi saddhiṁ pacitaṁ, taṁ rattavaṇṇaṁ_, “_Bila_: it is boiled together with a material that has the color red.”
pli-tv-kd6:9.2.2: _Piḷaka_. Sp.2.539: _Piḷakāti lohitatuṇḍikā sukhumapiḷakā_, “_Piḷaka_ is a minor _piḷaka_ with blood on the tip.” | _Thullakacchu_. Sp.2.539: _Thullakacchu vā ābādhoti mahāpiḷakābādho vuccati_, “_Thullakacchu vā ābādha_ is a sickness with large boils.”
pli-tv-kd6:9.2.3: [See essay on _chakaṇa_.] | [See essay on _Mattika_.] | _Rajananippakka_, lit. “dye that has been cooked”. The function here, too, is that of cleaning. Sp.3.264: _Rajananippakkanti rajanakasaṭaṁ. Pākatikacuṇṇampi koṭṭetvā udakena temetvā nhāyituṁ vaṭṭati; etampi rajananippakkasaṅkhepameva gacchati_, “_Rajananippakka_ are the dregs from dying. Having ground regular bathing powder, having moistened it, it is allowable to bathe. The same goes for _rajananippakka_.” Since dying and cleaning was often the same process in ancient India, the dying agent would have had cleansing properties. The dregs could therefore be used as a cleaning agent.
pli-tv-kd6:11.2.5: _Rasañjana_. Sp.3.365: _Rasañjanaṁ nānāsambhārehi kataṁ_, “_Rasañjana_ is made with many ingredients.” | _Sotañjana_. Sp.3.365: _Sotañjananti nadīsotādīsu uppajjanakaṁ añjanaṁ_, “_Sotañjana_: an ointment found in the stream of rivers.”
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.6: I here render _uccāvaca_ as luxurious. This rendering seems required by the context. See also use of this word at [sn2.29:7.1]().
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.12: _Phalamaya_. Khuddas-pṭ.185: _āmalakakakkādīhi katā phalamayā_, “Made of fruit means made from ground emblic myrobalan, etc.”
pli-tv-kd6:12.4.9: _Bandhanasuttaka_. Vin-ālaṅ-ṭ.34.67: _Añjanitthavikāya aṁse lagganatthāya aṁsabaddhakampi bandhanasuttakampi vaṭṭati_, “A shoulder strap and also a _bandhanasuttaka_ is allowed for the purpose of the hanging of the ointment-box bag from the shoulder.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.1: _Vātābādha_, lit. “a wind disease”. According to the Indian system of classification, this included a number of illnesses, such as arthritis. Since intestinal gas is elsewhere called _udaravātābādha_, “stomach wind disease”, it is unclear what is meant in this context. The commentaries are silent.
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.5: _Telapāka_. Sp.3.267: _Anujānāmi bhikkhave telapākanti yaṅkiñci bhesajjapakkhittaṁ sabbaṁ anuññātameva hoti_, “I allow _telapāka_: whatever medicines are included are all allowed.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.2.8: _Phalatumba_. Sp-ṭ̣.3.305: _Phalatumbo nāma lābuādi_, “A vessel made of fruit is a gourd, etc.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.3.1: “Arthiritis of the hands and feet” renders _aṅgavāta_, literally “wind of the limbs”. I follow the commentarial explanation at Sp.3.267: _Aṅgavātoti hatthapāde vāto_, “_Aṅgavāta_ means wind in the hands and the feet.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.3.6: _Sambhāraseda_. Sp.3.267: _Sambhārasedanti nānāvidhapaṇṇabhaṅgasedaṁ_, “_Sambhārasedanti_: sweating with various shredded leaves.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.3.12: _Bhaṅgodaka_. Sp.3.267: _Bhaṅgodakanti nānāpaṇṇabhaṅgakuthitaṁ udakaṁ; tehi paṇṇehi ca udakena ca siñcitvā siñcitvā sedetabbo_, “_Bhaṅgodaka_: water with various putrid, shredded leaves. One is made to sweat by repeated pouring the water and the leaves.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.3.15: _Udakakoṭṭhaka_. Sp.3.267: _Udakakoṭṭhakanti udakakoṭṭhe cāṭiṁ vā doṇiṁ vā uṇhodakassa pūretvā tattha pavisitvā sedakammakaraṇaṁ anujānāmīti attho_, “_Udakakoṭṭhaka_: the meaning is ‘I allow the causing of sweating by entering a tank or trough filled with hot water in a bathroom.’”
pli-tv-kd6:14.4.6: _Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, lohitaṁ mocetvā visāṇena gāhetunti_. I have not been able to trace any explanation of this, either in the commentaries or elsewhere.
pli-tv-kd6:14.5.3: _Kabaḷika_. Sp.3.267: _Kabaḷikanti vaṇamukhe sattupiṇḍaṁ pakkhipituṁ_, “_Kabaḷika_ means to place a lump of flour on the sore.” The definition in Dictionary of Pali is wrong.
pli-tv-kd6:14.5.13: _Vaḍḍhamaṁsa_. Sp.3.267: _Vaḍḍhamaṁsanti adhikamaṁsaṁ āṇi viya uṭṭhahati_, “_Vaḍḍhamaṁsa_ means an excess of flesh was sticking out like a peg.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.5.15: _Loṇasakkharikāya chindituṁ_. Sp.3.267: _Loṇasakkharikāya chinditunti khurena chindituṁ_, “_Loṇasakkharikāya chindituṁ_ means to cut with a razor.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.6: The question seems to be whether these can be given to the bitten person in an unreceived state, _appaṭiggahitāni_, or whether they have to be received first, _paṭiggahetabbānī_.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.1: _Gharadinnakābādha_. Sp.3.269: _Gharadinnakābādhoti vasīkaraṇapānakasamuṭṭhitarogo_, “_Gharadinnakābādha_ is a sickness coming from drinking an overpowering drink.” Sp-ṭ.3.3.269 adds: _Gharadinnakābādho nāma vasīkaraṇatthāya gharaṇiyā dinnabhesajjasamuṭṭhito ābādho_, “_Gharadinnakābādha_ is the name of a sickness coming from medicine given by a housewife for the purpose of overpowering.” The point seems to be that one is given a substance so that one can subsequently be overpowered.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.3: _Sītāloḷī_, lit. “what is mixed in a furrow”. Sp.3.269: _Sītāloḷinti naṅgalena kasantassa phāle laggamattikaṁ udakena āloḷetvā pāyetuṁ anujānāmīti attho_, “_Sītāloḷī_: the meaning is ‘I allow you to drink a mixture of water and the clay sticking to a plowshare of one plowing with a plow.’”
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.4: _Duṭṭhagahaṇika_. Sp.3.269: _Duṭṭhagahaṇikoti vipannagahaṇiko; kicchena uccāro nikkhamatīti attho_, “_Duṭṭhagahaṇiko_: one whose stomach has failed; the meaning is he has difficulties excreting feces.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.13: _Abhisannakāya_. Sp.3.269: _Abhisannakāyoti ussannadosakāyo_, “_Abhisannakāya_ means the body is full of impurities.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.21: _Akaṭayūsa_. Sp.3.269: _Akaṭayusanti asiniddho muggapacitapānīyo_, “_Akaṭayūsa_ is drinkable mung beans that have been boiled without oil.” Sp-ṭ.3.3.269, however, says: _Akaṭayūsenāti anabhisaṅkhatena muggayūsena_, “_Akaṭayūsena_ means the juice of unprepared mung beans.” This would seem to mean the raw juice of mung beans. I follow the more ancient authority.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.24: _Kaṭākaṭa_. Sp.3.269: _Kaṭākaṭanti sova dhotasiniddho_, “_Kaṭākaṭa_ the same (as the previous) but washed in oil.” Sp-ṭ.3.3.269, however, says: _Kaṭākaṭenāti mugge pacitvā acāletvāva parissāvitena muggasūpenāti_, “_Kaṭākaṭa_ means mung-bean soup made by boiling mung beans and then filtering it without stirring.” But this seems indistinguishable from the previous medicine, the mung-bean broth.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.27: _Paṭicchādanīyena_. Sp.3.269: _Paṭicchādanīyenāti maṁsarasena_, “_Paṭicchādanīyena_ means having the juice of meat.”
pli-tv-kd6:17.1.3: _Tekaṭulayāgu_. This is commonly rendered as “rice porridge having three pungent ingredients”. Yet rice and green gram can hardly be called pungent. I would suggest it is the taste of the combination of the three that is pungent.
pli-tv-kd6:17.2.4: _Setughāta_, lit. “destroyed the bridge”. Sp.1.16 comments: _Setu vuccati maggo, maggeneva tādisassa vacanassa ghāto, samucchedoti vuttaṁ hoti_, “The path is called the bridge; such speech is destroyed by the path.” The commentary seems to take _setu_, “bridge”, as a reference to the eightfold path. I prefer to understand “bridge” as a metaphor for access.
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.4: “The monks refused an invitation to eat more even after taking just a little” renders _appamattakepi pavārenti_. The phrase is explained in the subcommentary at Sp-ṭ̣.3.276: _Appamattakepi pavārentīti appamattakepi gahite pavārenti, “bahumhi gahite aññesaṁ nappahotī”ti maññamānā_, “_Appamattakepi pavārenti_: even when they have taken just little, they refuse an invitation to eat more, thinking, ‘If much is taken, there will not be enough for others.’”
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.5: They did not accept because they did not want to fall into an offense under _bhikkhu-pācittiya_ 35.
pli-tv-kd6:19.2.3: They did not accept because of _bhikkhu-pācittiya_ 35.
pli-tv-kd6:20.4.2: They did not accept because of _bhikkhu-pācittiya_ 35.
pli-tv-kd6:21.1.4: _Nibbattabīja_. _Nibbatta_ is a past participle that normally means “come into being” or “developed”. According to Monier-Williams’ Sanskrit English Dictionary (sv. _nir-vṛit_), however, it can also mean “removed”. Sp.3.278 says: _Nibbaṭṭabījanti bījaṁ nibbaṭṭetvā apanetvā paribhuñjitabbakaṁ ambapanasādi_, “_Nibbattabīja_ means having _nibbatta_-ed, having removed the seed, mangoes, jackfruit, etc. may be eaten.”
pli-tv-kd6:22.3.8: Vjb.3.279: _Sambādha_. _Sambādheti vaccamagge bhikkhussa bhikkhuniyā ca passāvamaggepi anulomato_, “_Sambādha_ means the anus of a monk or a nun, and also the genital area accords with this.”
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.10: That is, two finger-breadths. [See essay on Measures.] | _Vatthikamma_. Sp.3.279: _Yena kenaci pana cammena vā vatthena vā vatthipīḷanampi na kātabbaṁ_, “One should not do bladder-action, _vatthipīḷana_, with whatever skin or cloth.” Vmv.3.279: _Vatthipīḷananti yathā vatthigatatelādi antosarīre ārohanti, evaṁ hatthena vatthimaddanaṁ_, “_Vatthipīḷana_: in order for oils, etc. in a bladder to go up inside the body, thus one squeezes the bladder with the hand.” The meaning is not entirely clear. My rendering is no more than a suggestion.
pli-tv-kd6:23.2.7: “Ready meat” is for _pavattamaṁsa_. The Pali Text Society dictionary gives “raw meat”, but this seems to be a mistake.
pli-tv-kd6:24.6.1: This is partial parallel to AN 5.207 at [an5.207:0.3]().
pli-tv-kd6:25.1.2: “Thick rice porridge” is for _bhojjayāgu_. Sp.3.283: _Bhojjayāgunti yā pavāraṇaṁ janeti_, “_Bhojjayāgu_: what gives rise to satisfaction.” Vin-vn-ṭ.309 elaborates: _Ettha ca bhojjayāgu nāma bahalayāgu_, “In this case it is thick rice porridge that is called _bhojjayāgu_.”
pli-tv-kd6:26.6.5: _Appaharita_, lit. “few green plants”. According to _bhikkhu-pācittiya_ 19 at [Bu Pc 19:2.1.14](pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.14): _Haritaṁ nāma pubbaṇṇaṁ aparaṇṇaṁ_, “_Harita_ means: vegetables and grains.”
pli-tv-kd6:28.7.1: _Suññāgāra_. This normally means solitude or an empty dwelling, but here the context suggests another meaning is intended. DN-a.1.151, commenting on the parallel at DN16 ([dn16:1.25.4]()), says: _Suññāgāranti pāṭiyekkaṁ suññāgāraṁ nāma natthi, tattheva pana ekapasse sāṇipākārena parikkhipitvā – “idha satthā vissamissatī”ti mañcakaṁ paññapesuṁ_, “_Suññāgāra_: it is not a distinct (dwelling) that is called a _suññāgāra_. But they prepared a bed to one side right there, having surrounded it with a curtain, thinking, ‘The Teacher will rest here.’”
pli-tv-kd6:28.8.8: _Puṭabhedana_. See “Hoary Past and Hazy Memory”, by Oskar von Hinüber, p.203.
pli-tv-kd6:28.13.4: _Pallalāni_. I understand this as a poetic term for any body of water.
pli-tv-kd6:30.4.5: _Vesāliṁ sāhāraṁ_, lit. “Vesālī with its support”. Sp.3.289: _Sāhāraṁ dajjeyyāthāti sajanapadaṁ dadeyyātha_, “_Sāhāraṁ dajjeyyātha_ means you should give me (Vesālī) together with the country.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.1.1: _Santhāgāra_. This building seems to have been used for multiple purposes. In the present context it is used as a meeting place, the exact nature of the meeting not being spelled out. Other contexts show that the _santhāgāra_ was used for a number of purposes. At [mn51:10.3]() it is used as a place to perform a ritual; from [mn53:2.1]() and similar contexts we can deduce from the word _anajjhāvuṭṭha_, “not (previously) lived in”, that it was used as a place of lodging; at [dn3:1.13.4]() the Sakyans were enjoying themselves in their _santhāgāra_; according to [dn16:5.20.1]() and other _suttas_, the official meetings were held there; and at [sn56.45:1.3]() the Licchavī were practicing archery in the _santhāgāra_. By contrast the _sabhā_ seems to have been used exclusively for official meetings. As a consequence I translate _santhāgāra_ as “public hall” and _sabhā_ as “public meeting hall”.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.1: “Stilt house” combines _aḍḍhayoga_, _pāsāda_, and _hammiya _ in one word. See comment at [Kd 1:77.1.13](pli-tv-kd1:77.1.13) for an explanation.
pli-tv-kd6:33.5.8: _Ussāvanantika_. Sp.3.295: _Paṭhamathambhaṁ pana paṭhamabhittipādaṁ vā patiṭṭhāpentehi bahūhi samparivāretvā “kappiyakuṭiṁ karoma, kappiyakuṭiṁ karomā”ti vācaṁ nicchārentehi manussesu ukkhipitvā patiṭṭhāpentesu āmasitvā vā sayaṁ ukkhipitvā vā thambhe vā bhittipādo vā patiṭṭhāpetabbo_, “After the many who are installing have surrounded the first pillar or the first base for a wall, after extolling among people by saying, ‘We make a food-store’, having touched those who are installing or oneself having extolled, at the pillar or the base of the wall is to be established.” The details are not entirely clear, but the main point seems to be that one announces in the presence of others that one is building a food-store. | _Gonisādika_, lit. “a place where cows sit”. Sp.3.295: _Ettha kappiyakuṭiṁ laddhuṁ vaṭṭati_, “To obtain a food-store here is allowable.” I am not able to determine the precise meaning of this. | _Gahapati_. Sp.3.295: _Gahapatīti manussā āvāsaṁ katvā “kappiyakuṭiṁ dema, paribhuñjathā”ti vadanti_, “_Gahapati_: having made a building, the people say, ‘We give a food-store, please use it.’” | _Sammuti_. Sp.3.295: _Sammutikā nāma kammavācaṁ sāvetvā katāti_, “What is constructed/designated after making an official proclamation in the Sangha is called _sammutika_.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.2.2: _Catudoṇika piṭaka_, “A basket with a capacity of four _doṇas_.” According “On the Ancient Coins and Measures of Ceylon”, by Thomas Rhys Davids, p.18, one _doṇa_ is equivalent to 64 handfuls. It may well be that this amounts to more than one liter, but given the uncertainty one liter seems like a suitably round number.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.9: _Jātarūparajata_, lit. “gold and silver”, but this would have included gold and silver coins, that is, money. See _bhikkhu nissaggiya pācittiya_ 18 at [Bu NP 18:1.36](pli-tv-bu-vb-np18:1.36) where _rajata_ is defined as money, and the _Sattasatikakkhandhaka_, [Kd 22:1.1.10](pli-tv-kd22:1.1.10) and [Kd 22:1.1.15](pli-tv-kd22:1.1.15), where the context makes it clear that _jātarūparajata_ and _hirañña_ (gold) refer to money.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.3: _Cocapāna_. Sp.3.300: _Cocapānanti aṭṭhikehi kadaliphalehi katapānaṁ_, “_Cocapāna_: a drink made with plantain fruits that have seeds.” | _Mocapāna_. Sp.3.300: _Mocapānanti anaṭṭhikehi kadaliphalehi katapānaṁ_, “_Mocapāna_: a drink made with seedless plantain fruit.” | _Madhūkapāna_, lit. “a drink from the honey tree (fruit)”. Bassia latifolia or Madhuca longifolia. Sp.3.300: _Madhukapānanti madhukānaṁ jātirasena katapānaṁ_, “_Madhukapāna_: a drink made with the natural juice from honey tree fruits.” This might also refer to sap from the honey tree. | _Muddikapāna_. Sp.3.300: _Muddikapānanti muddikā udake madditvā ambapānaṁ viya katapānaṁ_, “_Muddikapāna_: having crushed grapes in water, it is a drink made like a mango drink.” | _Sālūkapāna_. Sp.3.300: _Sālūkapānanti rattuppalanīluppalādīnaṁ sālūke madditvā katapānaṁ_, “_Sālūkapāna_: a drink made by having crushed the tubers of red and blue lotuses.” | _Phārusakapāna_. Monier-Williams’ Sanskrit English Dictionary identifies this as the _Grewia Asiatica_, sv. _parūsha_. Sp.3.300: _Phārusakapānanti phārusakaphalehi ambapānaṁ viya katapānaṁ_, “_Phārusakapāna_: a drink made like a mango drink but with _phārusaka_ fruits.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.2: _Bhusāgāre_. Sp-ṭ.3.3.303: _Bhusāgāreti bhusamaye agārake_, “_Bhusāgāre_: a house made of husk.”
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.4: Sp.3.304: _Bhāgaṁ datvāti … bhūmisāmikānaṁ dātabbo_, “Having given a share: … it is to be given to the owners of the land.”
